keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man from Rhode Island, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008, with the first conviction occurring in August 2025 and the second expected in November 2025.
Rossi allegedly faked his death in 2020, with an obituary claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which was later discredited by police, his former lawyer, and a former foster family.
He fled the U.S. and was arrested in Scotland in 2024 after hospital staff recognized his tattoos from an Interpol notice, indicating a pattern of using aliases and evading law enforcement.
Rossi used at least a dozen aliases over the years to evade capture, including claiming to be an Irish orphan named Arthur Knight, and previously faced sex-related charges in Ohio.
Utah authorities identified him through a DNA match from a 2008 rape kit, part of a broader effort to clear backlogged rape kits.
In court, Rossi maintained his innocence, claiming the victims were lying, and did not testify during the trial.
The victim in the first case described the trauma of the assault and emphasized a plea for safety and accountability, highlighting the lasting emotional and psychological damage.
The judge described Rossi as a 'serial abuser of women' and a 'flight risk,' and sentenced him to five years to life in prison under Utah law.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man from Rhode Island with the legal name Nicholas Alahverdian, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008. After being identified through a DNA match from a decade-old rape kit, he allegedly faked his death in 2020 and fled the U.S., using multiple aliases including Arthur Knight. He was arrested in Scotland in 2024 after being recognized by hospital staff through his distinctive tattoos, including a Brown University crest. After a protracted extradition process, he was returned to Utah and sentenced in October 2025 to a prison term of five years to life for a first-degree rape felony. The victim described the trauma of the assault and emphasized a plea for safety and accountability. Prosecutors argued he was a dangerous flight risk, while Rossi maintained his innocence and claimed the victims were lying. The case highlights challenges in solving rape cases with backlogs, the use of international law enforcement cooperation, and the dangers of predatory behavior masked by online dating.
title: Man Accused of Faking His Own Death and Fleeing the US After Rape Charges Gets at Least Five Years in Prison
